terrain.surface: Gravel roads through MN North Shore. Moderate elevation with North Shore scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional MN event. Rolling terrain with moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Gun Flint 44 is a regional event in Grand Marais, Minnesota—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The North Shore scenery is nice, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Grand Marais provides moderate access.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional MN gravel race with North Shore rolling terrain. Worth it for MN/Midwest cyclists seeking a shorter event. Not a destination race for national travelers.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in MN/Midwest and want a local North Shore event—yes, it's solid. If you're from out of region—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For similar MN events: Gray Duck Grit. For longer MN events: other MN gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Grand Marais has moderate lodging options.
logistics.food: Grand Marais has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: MN North Shore rolling requires sustained effort.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with North Shore rolling terrain.

logistics.explanation: Research reveals confusion between Gun Flint 44 and the documented Gunflint Scramble 20-mile mountain bike race at Bearskin Lodge. No registration, packet pickup, or parking details available for the 44-mile version. Even basic race infrastructure remains undocumented.

length.explanation: 44 miles sits in the awkward middle distance between morning blast and epic bragging rights. All documented evidence points to a 20-mile Gunflint Scramble mountain bike race instead, making the actual distance questionable. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: The related Gunflint Scramble is described as 'fairly non-technical' with caution needed only on steep fast descents with loose terrain. Mix of wide nordic ski trails and forest roads suggests more grinding than technical challenge. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 2500 feet over 44 miles averages 57 feet per mile of climbing. Course promises 'punishing climbs' described as 'steep, long, loose, grassy' but no detailed elevation profile exists to verify the actual challenge level. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: October weather brings proper variability with highs in mid-50s but warnings to 'bring clothing for wide range of conditions.' Race runs rain or shine with backup gravel loops if trails get oversaturated by Forest Service requirements. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Northern Minnesota location means minimal elevation gain with no respiratory challenge. Starting elevation likely around 1000 feet with modest high points providing zero altitude training effect. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Remote nordic and snowmobile trails that 'seldom see use outside winter' deliver backcountry feel through Minnesota wilderness. Forest Service alternate course requirements suggest you're riding truly wild country, not manicured paths.

prestige.explanation: No gravel database contains Gun Flint 44 - searches only return the 20-mile Gunflint Scramble mountain bike race. No notable winners, pro field, or media coverage documented for any 44-mile gravel version.

race_quality.explanation: Race organization unclear with potential name confusion between events. The documented Gunflint Scramble offers .gpx files and well-marked routes but no aid station details or timing infrastructure mentioned for any 44-mile version.

experience.explanation: Bearskin Lodge start location adds charm to riding remote trails through Minnesota wilderness. The terrain delivers 'steep climbs, long climbs, loose climbs' promising proper suffering in beautiful country that rarely sees summer use.

community.explanation: The related Gunflint events draw competitive participants like dog mushers Erin Altemus and Rita Wehseler to the area. Local scene centered around Bearskin Lodge creates 'friendly atmosphere' for post-race gathering.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 200-400 riders, no field size data available with confusion over actual race format. The mountain bike version explicitly states gravel bikes 'wouldn't be any fun,' which would severely limit serious gravel participation. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Access to rarely-used trail systems in the remote Gunflint Trail area has inherent worth for wilderness riding. 44 miles through Minnesota backcountry offers solid adventure value despite unknown entry fees.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-100. Remote Grand Marais location requires driving time and distance with Bearskin Lodge accommodation likely at premium rates. No airport data available, meaning costly travel to Duluth or extended drive times. Higher total cost than Badlands.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
